Also within the Capitol Complex, this is the administrative office for the governments of Punjab and Haryana. The building's façade features a series of brise-soleil to mitigate sunlight.
This building houses the High Court for both states and is known for its imposing entrance and vibrant color palette, reflecting Le Corbusier's modernist principles.
An experimental structure by Le Corbusier, designed to demonstrate the effects of sunlight and shadow. It showcases innovative approaches to climate-responsive architecture.
Located at Panjab University, this building is dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi's life and philosophy. Designed by Pierre Jeanneret, it features a floating hyperbolic paraboloid roof over a pond.

Established in 1968, this museum houses a rich collection of Gandhara sculptures, Pahari and Rajasthani miniature paintings, and artifacts from the Indus Valley Civilization. The building reflects modernist design principles.
Founded in 1961, the college building exemplifies modernist educational architecture, aligning with the city's planned aesthetic and serving as a center for architectural education.

name: Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Dama

items.Description: Built by the Portuguese in the 16th century, Diu Fort is a massive fortification located on the west coast of India in Diu. It features double moat defenses, an array of cannons, and offers panoramic views of the Arabian Sea. The fort stands as a testament to Portuguese colonial architecture and maritime prowess.

Completed in 1610 in Diu, St. Paul's Church is a fine example of Baroque architecture in India. Dedicated to Our Lady of Immaculate Conception, it is renowned for its intricate woodwork, ornate façade, and shell-like motifs, reflecting the Portuguese influence in the region.

Constructed between 1559 and 1581, the Fort of Moti Daman in Daman encompasses an area of about 30,000 square meters. The fort's design includes ten bastions and two gateways, with the inner precinct housing the Cathedral of Bom Jesus, showcasing the colonial architectural heritage.

items.Architecture Name: Church of Our Lady of Piety
items.Description: Situated opposite the Tribal Museum in Silvassa, this church was built by the Portuguese in the late 18th century. Noted for its imposing Gothic architecture, the structure's grey stone exteriors bear a resemblance to Barcelona’s Sagrada Familia, reflecting the rich colonial past of Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

Also known as Nani Daman Fort, this fortification in Daman features a prominent gateway adorned with a statue of St. Jerome. Within its walls lies the Church of Our Lady of the Sea, exemplifying Portuguese colonial architecture and serving as a historical landmark.

Located near Fudam village in Diu, this unique cave temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and features five Shiva lingas believed to have been established by the Pandava brothers. The lingas are situated amidst rocks on the seashore and are often submerged during high tides, adding to the temple's distinctive charm.

Situated in Daman, the Governor's Palace is an architectural building of historical significance. While specific details about its construction and history are limited, it is recognized as a notable site in the region.

Located in Daman, Nagarseth Haveli is an architectural building known for its historical value. Detailed information about its architecture and history is scarce, but it stands as a point of interest in the area.
The Collector Office in Daman is noted as an architectural building. While specific architectural details are not extensively documented, it is listed among the notable structures in the region.
This building in Daman is recognized for its architectural significance. However, detailed information about its history and architectural style is limited.

Commissioned by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in 1638, the Red Fort served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors for nearly 200 years. Built from red sandstone, it exemplifies Mughal architecture with features like the Diwan-i-Aam and Diwan-i-Khas, and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Completed in 1220, the Qutub Minar is a 72.5-meter tall minaret, making it the world's tallest brick minaret. Initiated by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, it is an early example of Indo-Islamic architecture and is part of the Qutub complex, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Built in 1572, Humayun's Tomb is the first garden-tomb on the Indian subcontinent. Commissioned by Humayun's widow, Empress Bega Begum, it combines Persian and Mughal architectural elements and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Inaugurated in 1931, India Gate is a 42-meter tall war memorial designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens. It honors the Indian soldiers who died during World War I and the Third Anglo-Afghan War, and is a prominent example of British colonial architecture.

Completed in 1986, the Lotus Temple is a Bahá'í House of Worship known for its distinctive lotus-shaped design. Made of white marble, it serves as a symbol of unity and is open to people of all faiths.

Built between 1650 and 1656 by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, Jama Masjid is one of the largest mosques in India. Constructed with red sandstone and white marble, it features three domes and two minarets, exemplifying Mughal architectural grandeur.

Completed in 1929, Rashtrapati Bhavan serves as the official residence of the President of India. Designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, it is a blend of Western and Indian architectural styles, featuring a massive dome and expansive gardens.

Built in 1754, Safdarjung's Tomb is a sandstone and marble mausoleum of Nawab Safdarjung. It represents the last phase of Mughal architecture, with a central dome, large arched gateways, and extensive gardens.
Established in the 15th century, Lodhi Garden houses the tombs of Mohammed Shah and Sikandar Lodi. The garden showcases a blend of Sultanate and Mughal architectural styles amidst landscaped lawns.

Inaugurated in 2005, Akshardham Temple is a sprawling complex showcasing traditional Indian and Hindu architecture. Made of pink sandstone and white marble, it features intricate carvings, a central monument, and cultural exhibitions.

Located in Jammu, Mubarak Mandi Palace served as the royal residence of the Dogra Maharajas. The complex showcases a blend of Rajasthani, Mughal, and European architectural styles, featuring notable structures like the Pink Palace and the Gol Ghar.

Situated on the eastern side of Dal Lake in Srinagar, Nishat Bagh is a terraced Mughal garden built in 1633. Known as the 'Garden of Joy,' it features twelve terraces adorned with chinar and cypress trees, offering panoramic views of the lake.

Located in Srinagar, Khanqah-e-Moula is one of the oldest Muslim shrines in Kashmir, built in 1395 by Sultan Sikandar. The wooden structure is renowned for its intricate carvings, papier-mâché decorations, and traditional Kashmiri architecture.

Constructed in the 19th century in Jammu for Raja Amar Singh, this red sandstone palace exhibits French château-style architecture. It now functions as a museum, housing a significant collection of paintings, books, and a golden throne.

Built by Mughal Emperor Jahangir in 1619 in Srinagar, Shalimar Bagh is a celebrated Mughal garden. Designed with a central water channel, fountains, and terraced lawns, it exemplifies Mughal horticultural aesthetics.

Overlooking the town of Leh in Ladakh, this 17th-century palace was the former residence of the Namgyal dynasty. The nine-story structure, built of stone, wood, mud, and sand, reflects medieval Tibetan architecture.

Perched atop Hari Parbat hill in Srinagar, this fort was constructed under the reign of Afghan governor Atta Muhammad Khan in the 18th century. The fort offers insights into the military architecture of the period and provides panoramic views of the city.

Located in Charar-e-Sharief, this shrine is dedicated to the revered Kashmiri saint Sheikh Noor-ud-din Noorani. The wooden structure showcases traditional Kashmiri craftsmanship with its detailed woodwork and serene ambiance.

Situated approximately 19 kilometers east of Leh, Thiksey Monastery is a prominent Tibetan Buddhist monastery. Resembling the Potala Palace in Lhasa, it is known for its impressive architecture and a two-story statue of Maitreya Buddha.

Located in the heart of Srinagar's old city, this 14th-century mosque was commissioned by Sultan Sikandar. The mosque is notable for its Indo-Saracenic architecture, featuring 378 wooden pillars and a spacious courtyard.

Located approximately 19 kilometers east of Leh, Thiksey Monastery is a twelve-story complex situated on a hilltop. It is renowned for its resemblance to the Potala Palace in Lhasa, Tibet, and houses a notable 15-meter-high statue of Maitreya Buddha, the largest in Ladakh.

Situated about 45 kilometers south of Leh, Hemis Monastery is the largest and wealthiest monastery in Ladakh. Established in 1672 by King Sengge Namgyal, it is famous for its annual Hemis Festival, which celebrates the birth of Guru Padmasambhava.

Built in the 17th century by King Sengge Namgyal, Leh Palace is a nine-story structure that once served as the royal residence. Overlooking the town of Leh, it exemplifies medieval Tibetan architecture and offers panoramic views of the surrounding mountains.

Constructed in 1820 by King Tsepal Namgyal, Stok Palace is the current residence of the Namgyal dynasty. Located approximately 15 kilometers south of Leh, it houses a museum showcasing royal artifacts, including traditional clothing, jewelry, and ancient manuscripts.

Approximately 15 kilometers from Leh, Shey Monastery was once the summer capital of Ladakh. It features a 12-meter-high copper statue of Shakyamuni Buddha, gilded with gold, which was the largest Buddha statue in the region until the construction of the Maitreya Buddha at Thiksey.

Dating back to the 10th century, Alchi Monastery is one of the oldest in Ladakh. Unlike other monasteries built on hilltops, it is situated on flat ground near the Indus River. The complex is renowned for its well-preserved wall paintings and unique Kashmiri-influenced architecture.

Often referred to as the 'Moonland' due to its unique landscape, Lamayuru Monastery is one of the oldest and largest monasteries in Ladakh. Founded in the 11th century, it is known for its annual mask dance festival and houses numerous ancient artifacts.

Located in the Nubra Valley, Diskit Monastery was founded in the 14th century and is the oldest and largest monastery in the region. It is famous for its 32-meter-high statue of Maitreya Buddha, which overlooks the Shyok River.

Built into a cliffside in the remote Lungnak Valley, Phugtal Monastery resembles a honeycomb structure and is accessible only by foot. Established in the early 12th century, it remains one of the most isolated monasteries in Ladakh, preserving its traditional way of life.

Founded in the 11th century, Likir Monastery is known for its 23-meter-high gilded statue of Maitreya Buddha, one of the largest in Ladakh. The monastery houses a rich collection of thangkas, ancient manuscripts, and traditional artifacts.

Located on Kavaratti Island, the Mohidden Mosque, also known as the Ujra Mosque, dates back to the 17th century. It features an ornate ceiling carved from a single piece of driftwood and intricately carved pillars. A well within the mosque's precincts is believed to contain water with curative properties. The grave of Sheikh Mohammad Kasim, revered by locals, is also situated here.

Situated on Agatti Island, the Mohiyudeen Mosque is renowned for its architectural style reminiscent of 16th-century Malabar temples. Notably, the mosque lacks minarets, a rare feature in mosque architecture. The finely carved tombstones and overall design make it a significant religious site on the island.

Established on February 2, 1885, at the southern end of Minicoy Island, this 49.5-meter-tall lighthouse was built during the British era. Constructed with bricks brought from London, it features a cylindrical tower with a balcony and lantern. The lighthouse offers panoramic views of the Arabian Sea and remains a testament to colonial engineering.

In Lakshadweep, traditional island houses are constructed using locally sourced coral stones and timber. These structures are designed to suit the coastal environment, featuring sloped roofs to facilitate rainwater drainage and elevated platforms to protect against flooding. The architectural style reflects the adaptation of the islanders to their maritime surroundings.

Lakshadweep Bhavan is a vibrant community space that showcases a blend of traditional and contemporary architecture. Featuring a sloped roof, column structures, and design elements like grooves, it serves as a cultural hub for community gatherings and celebrations, reflecting the region's rich heritage.

items.Architecture Name: Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus
items.Description: Located on the south boulevard of Puducherry, this church is an example of Gothic architecture. It contains rare stained glass panels depicting events from the life of Christ and was built by French missionaries in the 18th century.

items.Architecture Name: Eglise de Notre Dame des Anges (The Church of Our Lady of Angels)
items.Description: Situated in Rue Dumas, this church is notable for its masonry, which uses the finest of limestone mixed with white of the egg, making for a texture identical to that of white marble. Modeled on the Basilica at Lourdes in southern France, it features paired Doric columns below and ionic above.

items.Architecture Name: Cathedral of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception
items.Description: First built in 1692 and taking its present shape in 1791, this cathedral on Cathedral Street is one of the oldest churches in Puducherry, reflecting French colonial architectural styles.

Completed in 1942, Golconde is a private residence for the Sri Aurobindo Ashram. Designed by architect Antonin Raymond, it is recognized as the first modernist building in India, utilizing reinforced concrete to mitigate the effects of the hot and humid climate.

Located in Villianur, this Hindu temple is dedicated to Shiva, represented by the lingam. The temple complex covers an area of two acres and features Dravidian architecture with concentric rectangular walls enclosing its shrines.

Also known as 'White Town,' this area showcases French colonial architecture with its straight, clean streets lined with mustard-yellow townhouses, colonial villas, and heritage buildings, reflecting the French influence on the city's urban planning and design.

In contrast to the French Quarter, the Tamil Quarter features traditional Tamil architecture with houses characterized by thinnai (raised platforms), open courtyards, and colonnaded structures, illustrating the blend of Tamil and colonial architectural styles.

Serving as the official residence of the Lieutenant Governor of Puducherry, Raj Niwas is a colonial-era building that exemplifies French architectural design, featuring grand facades and well-maintained gardens.

This ancient temple, dedicated to Lord Ganesha, existed before the French settled in Puducherry. It features a golden spire and walls portraying forty different forms of Ganesha, reflecting traditional Dravidian temple architecture.

Located in Bharathi Park, this white monument was built during the time of Napoleon III. It is named after Aayi, a 16th-century courtesan who, according to legend, destroyed her own house to build a reservoir for the city, symbolizing the blend of local history and French colonial architecture.
